awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Polymer Single Crystal-Assisted "Grafting From": A Versatile Approach towards Multicomponent Polymer Brushes with Well-Defined Architectures and Grafting
awd_abstract_narration:
The surface properties of a material can be critical to its application (e.g., the adhesive properties of tapes, non-wetting properties of water-repellent garments, and non-stick surface of cookware).  Often, the material surface needs to be chemically modified to tailor its properties.  In this collaborative research, Professor Bin Zhao of the University of Tennessee Knoxville and Professor Christopher Li of Drexel University develop a viable method for modifying a surface with a polymer containing a well-defined architecture and thus achieving precise control of surface structures and properties.  This fundamental chemistry research is expected to advance the field of polymer science and present new opportunities in materials and technology development.  Additional broader impacts of the project include education and training of undergraduate and graduate students in both polymer chemistry and physics, preparing a workforce for the polymer (plastics) industry.  Polymer chemistry is integrated in outreach activities (e.g., demonstration experiments such as "Foam and Slime Forming" in a Drexel summer outreach program) for high school teachers and students to arouse their interests in science. 

The Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the NSF Chemistry Division supports this research to develop a robust and versatile strategy for preparing a variety of well-defined multicomponent polymer brushes on flat solid substrates (e.g., silicon wafers and glass substrates).  This research aims to combine polymer single crystal-assisted "grafting to" and surface-initiated "living"/controlled polymerization (i.e., "grafting from") to synthesize brushes with complex architectures, such as Y-shape and loop, and tunable grafting densities.  Various polymerization methods (including ring-opening polymerization, atom transfer radical polymerization, and nitroxide-mediated radical polymerization) are used to synthesize the multicomponent polymer brushes.  A range of techniques (e.g., atomic force microscopy, x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, scanning and transmission electron microscopies, grazing incident small-angle X-ray scattering, and wide angle X-ray diffraction) are used to characterize the polymer brush structures and properties.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Polymer brushes, consisting of an assembly of polymer chains densely tethered by one or more points via covalent bonds to a substrate, have received tremendous interest in the past decades because of their intriguing structures and properties as well as potential applications in numerous areas. The substrate can be a flat surface (e.g., glass), a curved surface (e.g., particles), a “line” (single-walled carbon nanotube or a polymer chain), or a “point” (e.g., core in multiarm star copolymers or small nanoparticles). Polymer brushes are typically prepared by three approaches: (i) physisorption of block copolymers, (ii) “grafting to”, where an end- or center-functionalized polymer is grafted onto a substrate, and (iii) “grafting from”,  where an initiator is immobilized on a substrate first, followed by growing polymer chains from the substrate in situ. This collaborative research project is aimed at fabricating well-defined multicomponent polymer brushes using a new approach by employing polymer-single-crystal (PSC)-assisted “grafting-to” (PSCAGT) and surface-initiated “living”/controlled polymerization techniques. PSCAGT is a newly developed method for the synthesis of well-defined polymer brushes that provides many advantages, including pre-determined and precisely controlled grafting density, end-group functionality, tunable brush pattern, etc. However, this method is restricted to semicrystalline polymers. To broaden PSCAGT and expand its application, a team of two research groups with complementary expertise (Li: polymer physics and polymer brushes; Zhao: polymer synthesis and polymer brushes) was formed for the synthesis of well-defined multicomponent polymer brushes by combining PSCAGT and surface-initiated controlled polymerization techniques. Under this grant, a variety of novel brush architectures including well-controlled gradient and patterned brushed, nanoframes, and block copolymer brushes, were achieved.  These results demonstrated the versatility of PSCAGT for polymer brush synthesis. Furthermore, a new polymer brush-based approach for the fabrication of patchy nanoparticles (NPs) with a small number of nanodomains was discovered. These brush NPs exhibited abilities to form “bonds” through the overlap of nanodomains and to change the valency when interacting with adjacent NPs. This exciting discovery will likely trigger more studies on patchy/multivalent hairy NPs, from the synthesis to the assembly into functional nanomaterials. Both Li and Zhao groups are committed to mentoring graduate and undergraduate students and outreaching to K-12 students. The Li group has also been actively involved in activities such as Philly Materials Day, Materials Summer Camp, etc. Research work has been disseminated via publishing the results in scientific journals and delivering presentations in national and international meetings.

 

 


Last Modified: 12/13/2021
Modified by: Christopher Li
